@n_the_mountains  100% correct .. so it is self-defeating.
“communicating a path for the policy rate via the median of the SEP could be viewed as an inadvertent calendar-based commitment” -Bullard
and econ forecasting is obviously very hard ... which is why you forecast often*
In my view, the *value* in the SEP is to share the $FED forecast for achieving their mandate, not to specify future level of rates.
I was impressed to see $FED Bullard catch this oversight ... you should not be *data-dependent* AND have a dot-plot.  They conflict.
The next $FED meeting in mid-March will be followed by a press conference and updated SEP projections.

Fed’s Neel Kashkari: Break Up the Big Banks 

https://t.co/F9a6GsCTXT
but @neelkashkari is def right about one thing ... now is the time to do this work ... not during the crisis.  but we wont. a shame.
we also need to recognize how CDS can mess-up the economics of debt workouts and impose logical rules for who can buy them.
so we ought to empower the $FED to fix the discount window and stop the feedback loop anytime there is a bank run on a *good* bank.
and banking is unique ... in that a totally safe bank following all the rules is still susceptible to a run in a panic ...
one big problem is we had entities selling *insurance* ... but avoiding the rules by calling it s.th else.  that wont stop.
and there are many proven ways to de-risk banking ... including capital ratios, leverage, debt/equity structure, etc.   who cares about size
i realize this is a unpopular opinion ... but i do not believe bank size is the problem.  i would rather we focus on risk, not size.
